text: it is a hundred days since Boris Johnson
announced the start of the lockdown
and despite measures being eased
throughout most of the UK many residents
in care homes are still unable to see
family and friends over the past few
months one care home resident has been
telling us of his worry and isolation
our social affairs correspondent Allison
Holt has the story
I do like fresh air
so my windows are open throughout the
year Rob is in his mid-40s and has been
living in a care home for four years the
garden is hidden at the moment because
I'm not supposed to leave my room even
before the lockdown I didn't go to the
garden as direct sunlight messes me up
and I don't like rain we've asked an
actor to speak Robb's words like many
care home residents he's totally reliant
on others so he's worried about being
identified his movements very limited
but over several weeks typing with one
finger he's told us about the impact of
kovat 19 on him the consensus about care
home residents is that they are all old
and nobody cares wrong I have a
progressive illness it has made my
speech virtually unintelligible however
my eyes ears and brain are unaffected so
I see and hear things that can't say
anything for weeks he's been unable to
leave his room has all his meals there
and as no visitors are allowed only sees
his family online the care I am getting
is adequate I'm extremely anxious scared
about the lack of training and
management of carers you can't explain
the infection control with a glare for
goodness sake
most of them struggle with the idea ie
using their personal mobile phones in my
room after putting on their gloves I
have a Wi-Fi printer so occasion I print
as a message for them but I suspect that
many of the carers can't read English as
the coronavirus took hold
the outside world residents in Rob's
home began to show signs of the virus at
least five have since died he fears it
could be more it's terrifying
I used the word terrifying because I am
scared I don't like being totally
helpless Rob feels he's been kept in the
dark about what's happened in the home
the company has not provided any
information about this possible
infection this is very serious and I'm
fed up so right from the start we've
tried to throw a protective ring around
our calves the comment from Matt Hancock
about putting a ring of protection
around care homes comes with no evidence
at all and in my opinion it was
thoroughly insulting living inside a
care home he's felt forgotten by
government and isolated from the world
there are a lot of things that conspired
to make things worse but nothing should
have been insurmountable and as lockdown
eases for others he wants to make sure
the voices of care home residents like
him are being heard Allison Holt BBC
news
